text.tspan: In most of today's applications and websites, designers have made the choice of using what they call
"symbolic icons". These are really schematic icons, without border or shadow/3D effects, that can be
easily scaled to any size, and/or colored into any color (generally to match the color of text near them).
Modern Icons Design Guidelines
This document tries to expose practical usecases that demonstrate why using symbolic icons can save
a LOT of time while developing a new product and the other advantages it brings.
1/ Scalability
2/ Coloring and contrast
3/ Alignment, margins, and size-factor...
x3
OK.
x3
NOT OK !
Here we started with 1px border,
and we end up with 3px.
That may sound right but it is not :
If source/target size was different,
we could have different border size
between icons, and even have
not-integer border (blur rendering).
(Also, icons with really small details can become unlegible at small size, so prefer using simple symbols.)
NOTE : All this content assumes designer is using a scalable image format (like SVG or EPS).
It seems pointless to argue why scalable is better than pixel maps, so it won't be done here.
It can be really hard to have a good contrast between icons and its background when the icon is complex,
because we can't simply change the color, and we often end up creating many variants of the same image,
just with color or border changing from one to the other :
None of these images are perfectly contrasted,
despite having already multiple variants of it.
It would be much simpler to have only one image
and use the complementary color of background.
It can get really hard to have a good contrast when having to take in account the 3 background/border/foreground colors.
And virtually, we can end up creating all combination of these 3 colors, which can go up to 9 (duplicates ignored...).
Using a monochromatic symbol helps hugely because it can be simply rendered with any color in the palette, and we don't
have to care about the border color. It leaves at the same time an infinity of possibilities, and a unique source image !
To be able to scale effeciently the symbols and keep the alignments and proportions between icons in
a given page, we have to enforce a limited set of size factors (ratio between width and height) and use
fixed padding inside the icon source image (to simplify, fit the icon in the image with no margin).
Using icons with different size-factors causes a lot of issues when scaling : let's say we decide to give the
same height to all icons and keep the ratio for width, we will break alignment between icons on the page.
And if we do the opposite, keep same width and apply ratio on the height, we break the size proportions
between icons of the page. So basically none of these two options are acceptable.
To keep it simple : all icons of the same group must share the same size-factor. And to avoid having to
handle tens of factors in the UI, we can simply create 3 groups and enforce the ratio within these groups :
width
height
Square
Horizontal
Vertical
Within these groups, the source image
can have any size, as long as the width/height
ratio is honored. This ease-up greatly the
design process, and also the integration within
the UI later.
